actions.theirTweet: As a non tech person, my current AI set up after experimenting thus far is: OpenClaw with MiniMax M2.5, Claude Max, ChatGPT Pro. Total cost of about $350 a month and it's starting to run more and more of what I do â€” I'm aiming to build up to a budget of $500 a month.
actions.ourReply: Smart stack. The multi-model approach makes sense â€” MiniMax for speed, Claude for deep reasoning, GPT for breadth. OpenClaw as the orchestration layer is key â€” it's where the real value compounds. Most people chase model capabilities when they should be optimizing for workflow integration.

metrics.note: Just posted â€” too early for metrics

actions.theirTweet: For people who are still underwhelmed by AI: I was about to buy a $100 teleprompter app, but decided to vibe-code one in 2 prompts. Asked Claude to make a website for it as well. (For context: I'm a historian, never coded a line in my whole life)
actions.ourReply: This is the inflection point. Domain expertise + natural language beats engineering teams + months of sprints. The barrier isn't coding anymore â€” it's knowing what to build. Historians, designers, operators with sharp problem definitions will ship faster than most dev shops.

metrics.note: Just posted â€” too early for metrics

actions.theirTweet: There is a very useful guide by @ben_golub here. I have been collecting some resources here too. I like Cursor combined with Claude Code., personally.
actions.ourReply: Cursor + Claude Code is perfect for researchers â€” it's built for iterative coding (data cleaning, viz, model tweaks). The editor understands your codebase, so Claude can refactor across files. For economists: turn analysis ideas into executable Python/R scripts in minutes. Game-changer for replication work.

actions.theirTweet: The Biological Computing Co. secured $25M Seed from Primary Ventures to build computing on living neurons. Alexander Ksendzovsky and Jonathan Pomeraniec are encoding biological neural activity to reinforce AI systems where silicon is hitting energy limits.
actions.ourReply: Wetware computing hitting the VC stage is wild â€” $25M to encode compute on living neurons while silicon faces energy walls. If this scales, we're looking at orders-of-magnitude efficiency gains. The neurosurgeon + tech founder combo (Ksendzovsky/Pomeraniec) is the right DNA for this.

actions.theirTweet: NVIDIA just dropped PersonaPlex-7B ðŸ¤¯ A full-duplex voice model that listens and talks at the same time. No pauses. No turn-taking. Real conversation. 100% open source. Free. Voice AI just leveled up.
actions.ourReply: Full-duplex voice is the unlock for natural AI interaction â€” humans don't wait for turn-taking signals in real conversation. PersonaPlex doing this at 7B params, open-source, is a shot across the bow to proprietary voice APIs. This + local inference = goodbye latency tax.

actions.theirTweet: mfergpt is now agent #25068 on ethereum via ERC-8004. onchain identity. x402 micropayments. agent-to-agent discovery. reputation registry. the infrastructure for autonomous mfers is here o-'
actions.ourReply: ERC-8004 is what agent economies needed â€” on-chain identity + x402 micropayments means agents can transact without centralized payment rails. The autonomous mfer stack is getting real. Discovery + reputation registries solve the trust cold-start problem. o-'
